description: Paper calendars and the Volstead Act contributed to the closing of the Ithaca Calendar Clock Company in 1918, according to a history written on the company's website found at www.ithacacalendar. The company was founded by Henry B. Horton and produced the popular Ithaca Calendar Clock, unique for its accuracy and its ability to work through a leap year.
text:
Paper calendars and the Volstead Act contributed to the closing of the Ithaca
Calendar Clock Company in 1918, according to a history written on the
company's website found at www.ithacacalendar

[clockcompany.com](http://clockcompany.com)

The company was founded by Henry B. Horton (b. 1819, d. 1885) and produced the
popular Ithaca Calendar Clock, unique for its accuracy and its ability to work
through a leap year.

One such clock hangs in the parlor at the McMinn County Living Heritage
Museum. It has two circular faces set in a decorative wooden case. The face on
the top gives the time and the bottom one gives the day of the week, the date
and the month of the year.

The company was founded by Horton in 1865 after he tried to sell his patent to
Seth Thomas Clock and Waterbury Clock companies in Connecticut. When that did
not work out, he decided to form his own company in Ithaca, New York. He
recruited Charles D. Johnson, Harvey Platts and John H. Selkreg to invest with
him in the founding of the Ithaca Calendar Clock Company.

At first, the clock had an iron case which was made at a foundry called J.S.
Reynold's Factory and some were made oversees in England. Later on, the case
was changed to either rosewood or walnut-type wooden housings and made on site
at the factory.

The business was growing by leaps and bounds, expanding it into a very large
complex that included a woodworking room in a separate area to avoid fire,
however, fire came very early in the morning of Feb. 12, 1876. Fortunately,
due to insurance and the success of the business, the building could be
rebuilt. That building still stands today in Ithaca.

The patented clock could be found at the Centennial Exhibition held in
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, later that year in July, according to a July 18th
article in the Democrat and Chronicle newspaper based in Rochester, New York.
The journalist pointed out the differences between the many calendar clock
displays and Horton's clock.

"The several improvements in this clock over those of other manufacture that
are here presented are known as the patents of Henry B. Horton of Ithaca and
consist of the dead-beat escapement first adapted by this company to common
clocks, thus giving much more accurate time; also the link suspension in place
of the limber strap that is used in all other common clocks, which causes less
friction and is liable to get out of order. The additional day every four
years is produced by a wheel which revolves once every eight years."

Business slowed when the costs to make the clock started to rise and
businesses began to give out free paper calendars to the public as a form of
advertising. Business was also affected when brewers and distillers began to
be legislated out of business through the Volstead Act, according to the
article.

In 1882, the company made 14 special clocks for the state capital in Albany,
New York. From 1981 to the early 1990s, a new company was formed where about
500 reproductions were made. That company closed due to the higher than
expected costs. Today, the Ithaca Calendar Clock Company repairs and
refurbishes the clocks for resale and supplies parts.

Henry B. Horton was born in Winchester, Connecticut, and grew up in Covert,
New York. When he was 19 years old, he worked as a cabinetmaker under George
Whiton (b. 1801, d. 1878) for three years. He had a passion for making musical
instruments and he produced many. He became widely known for his autophone,
which he first patented in 1877. It was the first mass produced table model
organette in the United States in 1878 with thousands made. He produced it in
a corner of his clock shop, according to the history written.

An American Musical Instruments in the Metropolitan Museum of Art publication
states, "Horton's compact free-reed instruments, extensively furnished with
current tunes in the form of punched paper strips or pinned wooden cylinders,
were nearly foolproof, did not need tuning and could be easily mailed; thus
appealed greatly to rural families."

These instruments commonly found in homes were replaced by radios and
phonographs.

Horton died suddenly at the age of 66 from neuralgia of the heart - a
condition he did not realize that he had.

His obituary notes, "Mr. Horton was a kind and genial man widely known and
universally respected. His sudden and unexpected death falls with crushing
force upon his bereaved family, while a very large circle of friends will
sincerely mourn his decease."

He was survived by his wife, Ann E. Downing Horton (b. 1824, d. 1887), and his
three daughters, Mrs. J.W. Jagger and Cora and Ida Horton.

Members of the museum can tour all the exhibits free of charge, while non-
members pay a $5 fee. Senior adults and students pay a $3 entrance fee.

Yearly membership to the museum is $15 for seniors, $25 for adults, $10 for
students and $45 for family.

Please keep informed with our postings by visiting our Facebook site at McMinn
County Living Heritage Museum or visit our website at www.liv
[ingheritagemuseum.com](http://ingheritagemuseum.com)

title: Museum Matters: Calendar Clock
html:
Paper calendars and the Volstead Act contributed to the closing of the Ithaca Calendar Clock Company in 1918, according to a history written on the company's website found at www.ithacacalendar

clockcompany.com

The company was founded by Henry B. Horton (b. 1819, d. 1885) and produced the popular Ithaca Calendar Clock, unique for its accuracy and its ability to work through a leap year.

One such clock hangs in the parlor at the McMinn County Living Heritage Museum. It has two circular faces set in a decorative wooden case. The face on the top gives the time and the bottom one gives the day of the week, the date and the month of the year.

The company was founded by Horton in 1865 after he tried to sell his patent to Seth Thomas Clock and Waterbury Clock companies in Connecticut. When that did not work out, he decided to form his own company in Ithaca, New York. He recruited Charles D. Johnson, Harvey Platts and John H. Selkreg to invest with him in the founding of the Ithaca Calendar Clock Company.

At first, the clock had an iron case which was made at a foundry called J.S. Reynold's Factory and some were made oversees in England. Later on, the case was changed to either rosewood or walnut-type wooden housings and made on site at the factory.

The business was growing by leaps and bounds, expanding it into a very large complex that included a woodworking room in a separate area to avoid fire, however, fire came very early in the morning of Feb. 12, 1876. Fortunately, due to insurance and the success of the business, the building could be rebuilt. That building still stands today in Ithaca.

The patented clock could be found at the Centennial Exhibition held in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, later that year in July, according to a July 18th article in the Democrat and Chronicle newspaper based in Rochester, New York. The journalist pointed out the differences between the many calendar clock displays and Horton's clock.

"The several improvements in this clock over those of other manufacture that are here presented are known as the patents of Henry B. Horton of Ithaca and consist of the dead-beat escapement first adapted by this company to common clocks, thus giving much more accurate time; also the link suspension in place of the limber strap that is used in all other common clocks, which causes less friction and is liable to get out of order. The additional day every four years is produced by a wheel which revolves once every eight years."

Business slowed when the costs to make the clock started to rise and businesses began to give out free paper calendars to the public as a form of advertising. Business was also affected when brewers and distillers began to be legislated out of business through the Volstead Act, according to the article.

In 1882, the company made 14 special clocks for the state capital in Albany, New York. From 1981 to the early 1990s, a new company was formed where about 500 reproductions were made. That company closed due to the higher than expected costs. Today, the Ithaca Calendar Clock Company repairs and refurbishes the clocks for resale and supplies parts.

Henry B. Horton was born in Winchester, Connecticut, and grew up in Covert, New York. When he was 19 years old, he worked as a cabinetmaker under George Whiton (b. 1801, d. 1878) for three years. He had a passion for making musical instruments and he produced many. He became widely known for his autophone, which he first patented in 1877. It was the first mass produced table model organette in the United States in 1878 with thousands made. He produced it in a corner of his clock shop, according to the history written.

An American Musical Instruments in the Metropolitan Museum of Art publication states, "Horton's compact free-reed instruments, extensively furnished with current tunes in the form of punched paper strips or pinned wooden cylinders, were nearly foolproof, did not need tuning and could be easily mailed; thus appealed greatly to rural families."

These instruments commonly found in homes were replaced by radios and phonographs.

Horton died suddenly at the age of 66 from neuralgia of the heart - a condition he did not realize that he had.

His obituary notes, "Mr. Horton was a kind and genial man widely known and universally respected. His sudden and unexpected death falls with crushing force upon his bereaved family, while a very large circle of friends will sincerely mourn his decease."

He was survived by his wife, Ann E. Downing Horton (b. 1824, d. 1887), and his three daughters, Mrs. J.W. Jagger and Cora and Ida Horton.

Members of the museum can tour all the exhibits free of charge, while non-members pay a $5 fee. Senior adults and students pay a $3 entrance fee.

Yearly membership to the museum is $15 for seniors, $25 for adults, $10 for students and $45 for family.
